docs.title: The Vampire Tracker API: Immortal Data Tracked Instantly
docs.text:
The Vampire Tracker API (Vampy API) is a small, focused REST API for exploring notable vampires across film, television, literature, and lore. It provides a structured, searchable, and canonical data source that you can plug into demos, prototypes, workshops, and teaching materials.

Built on json-server for simplicity and easy local setup, the Vampy API lets you query detailed information about individual vampires, their special powers, and the media where they appear.

docs.title: The Vampy data model at a glance
docs.text:
The Vampy API exposes three primary, interconnected resources. Together they form a small graph you can query in many ways:

  • /vampires – Core vampire profiles, including name, traits, and identifiers used to join to other resources.
  • /media – Film, TV, books, and other appearances, each linked to a specific vampire via vampireId.
  • /specialPowers – Unique or notable abilities, also linked to vampires via vampireId.

By combining these resources, you can answer questions like:

  • “Which powers does this vampire have?”
  • “In which movies has this vampire appeared?”
  • “Which vampires share a specific ability?”

docs.title: Why use the Vampy API?
docs.text:
The Vampy API gives you:

  • Consistent data model – A single source of truth for vampire facts, so your examples and demos stay accurate.
  • Familiar REST interface – Standard HTTP verbs and JSON responses make it easy to integrate with any HTTP client.
  • Rich relationships – Linked resources for vampires, media, and special powers so you can build realistic scenarios and queries.

docs.title: How this documentation is organized
docs.text:
Use these sections depending on where you are in your journey:

Section Best for What you’ll find Getting started First-time setup and your first request How to run the API locally and make an initial GET /vampires call. Tutorials Guided, task-based learning Step‑by‑step flows like adding vampires, filtering by powers, and managing media. Reference Looking up fields, endpoints, and behaviors Resource schemas, endpoints, query parameters, filtering, sorting, and examples.

docs.title: Get started in a few minutes
docs.text:
1. Spin up the API by following the Getting started guide.
  2. Make your first request using your favorite HTTP client (for example, GET /vampires).
  3. Explore deeper:
  4. Work through the tutorials to add, filter, and update vampires.
  5. Browse the Vampy API reference for endpoints and query options.

docs.title: Ready to sink your teeth in?
docs.text: Head to Getting started to launch the API and make your first call, then keep the reference and tutorials handy as you build.

docs.title: Becoming familiar: Getting started with the Vampy API
docs.text:
This tutorial guides you through the essential steps required to run the Vampire Tracker API (Vampy API) locally using json-server, plus the optional setup for issuing requests through Postman. By the end you will have the REST API running at http://localhost:3000 and, if desired, the Vampy Postman environment imported for GUI-based testing.

Procedures throughout this documentation set use {base_url} as replaceable variable. If you follow the instructions in this guide, {base_url} will be replaced with http://localhost:3000.

Procedures throughout this documentation set are intended for MacOS or Linux. CLI procedures for Windows OS might be different.

Expect this preparation to take about 20 minutes to complete.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, ensure that you meet the following prerequisites:

  • Node.js, which is used for running JavaScript packages.
  • json-server, which is used to host our API endpoints from the JSON database file.
  • git command line tool, which is used to clone the repository.

docs.title: Getting the project files
docs.text:
The following procedure shows you how to clone the Github repository.

  1. Open a terminal. Ensure that you are in the $HOME directory by running the following command:

    
cd $HOME

  2. Clone the project by running the following command:

    
git clone https://github.com/stevsmit/vampy-api.git

docs.title: Starting the Vampy API server
docs.text:
The following procedure shows you how to start the Vampy API data.

  1. Navigate into the vampy-api/api directory by running the following command:

    
cd vampy-api/api

  2. Start the JSON server by running the following command:

    
json-server vampy_db.json

    Your terminal will show confirmation messages that the server is running and the available resources:

    \{^_^}/ hi!

Loading vampy_db.json
Done

Resources
http://localhost:3000/vampires
http://localhost:3000/media
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers

Home
http://localhost:3000

Type s + enter at any time to create a snapshot of the database

docs.title: Importing the Postman environment
docs.text:
If you prefer to issue requests from Postman instead of curl, import the bundled environment so the tutorials can reference ready-made variables.

  1. In your file explorer, locate the postman directory inside the cloned repository. It contains vampy-api-local.postman_environment.json.

  2. Open Postman and click the Environments icon next to the workspace selector.

  3. Click Import, select the vampy-api-local.postman_environment.json file, and confirm the import.

  4. On the Environment tab, click Set Active to activate the Vampy API workspace.

  5. Optional: Verify the environment by opening a new request tab and entering {{baseUrl}}/vampires. When you click Send, the request should resolve to http://localhost:3000/vampires.

docs.title: About the /media resource
docs.text: The /media resource represents a media appearance associated with a vampire in the Vampy API. Each entry includes the title of the media, its release year, and a foreign key (vampireId) linking the appearance to a specific vampire. You can create, read, update, or delete media entries using the corresponding API endpoints.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text: Property Type Description Example id integer Unique identifier for this entry. 1 type string The medium where the vampire appears (for example, movie, television, book, etc.) movie title string The title of the work "Underworld" vampireId integer Links to the specific vampire in the vampires resource. 1 year integer The year of the media's release or publication. 2003

docs.title: Related endpoints
docs.text: Path Description GET /media Retrieve a list of all media entries. GET /media/{id} Retrieve a single media entry by its id. GET /media?vampireId={id} Retrieve all media entries linked to a specific vampire. POST /media Create a new media entry. PATCH /media/{id} Update one or more fields of an existing media entry. PUT /media/{id} Replace an existing media entry with a new object (all fields required). DELETE /media/{id} Delete a media entry.

docs.title: About the /specialPowers resource
docs.text: The /specialPowers resource represents individual supernatural abilities associated with vampires in the Vampy API. Each entry includes the name of the power and a foreign key (vampireId) linking the ability to a specific vampire. You can create, read, update, or delete special power entries using the corresponding API endpoints.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text: Property Type Description Example id integer Unique identifier for the special power entry. 1 power string Name of the special ability. "Day-walking" vampireId integer Links to the specific vampire in the vampires resource. 7

docs.title: Related endpoints
docs.text: Path Description GET /specialPowers Retrieve a list of all special powers. GET /specialPowers/{id} Retrieve a single special power entry by its id. GET /specialPowers?vampireId={id} Retrieve all powers linked to a specific vampire. POST /specialPowers Create a new special power entry. PATCH /specialPowers/{id} Update one or more fields of a special power entry. PUT /specialPowers/{id} Replace an existing special power entry with a new object (all fields required). DELETE /specialPowers/{id} Delete a special power entry.

docs.title: About the /vampires resource
docs.text: The /vampires resource represents a vampire profile in the Vampy API. Each entry contains the vampire's name, abilities, and unique identifier. This resource is central to link media appearances and special powers. You can create, read, update, or delete vampire profiles using the corresponding API endpoints.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text: Property Type Description Example id integer Unique identifier for the vampire 1 name string The common name or title of the vampire. "Selene" canFly boolean Indicates whether the vampire is capable of flight in their base form. true batMode boolean Indicates whether the vampire can transform into a bat. false

docs.title: Related endpoints
docs.text: Path Description GET /vampires Retrieve a list of all vampire profiles. GET /vampires/{id} Retrieve a single vampire profile by its id. GET /vampires?canFly={true/false} Retrieve all vampires that can or cannot fly. GET /vampires/{id}?_embed=specialPowers Retrieve a vampire profile along with its assigned special powers. GET /vampires/{id}?_embed=media Retrieve a single vampire profile and embed all associated media appearances in the response. POST /vampires Create a new vampire profile. Requires name, canFly, and batMode. PATCH /vampires/{id} Update one or more fields on an existing vampire. PUT /vampires/{id} Replace an existing vampire with a new object (all fields required). DELETE /vampires/{id} Delete a vampire profile.

docs.title: API reference: REST operations
docs.text:
The Vampy API supports standard RESTful operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on all three primary resources: /vampires, /media, and /specialPowers. All requests and responses are handled via JSON.

This reference provides a high-level overview of each operation, with examples for common use cases.

docs.title: Read operations (GET)
docs.text:
Use GET to retrieve Vampy API resources. You can fetch all resources, a single resource by ID, or filter resources based on certain fields. You can also expand related resources using _embed.

Operation Endpoint example Description Get all vampires GET /vampires Retrieve a list of all vampire profiles. Get vampire by ID GET /vampires/7 Retrieve the profile for the vampire with id=7 (Blade). Filter vampires GET /vampires?canFly=true Retrieve all vampires capable of flight. Vampire with embedded media GET /vampires/1?_embed=media Retrieve a vampire profile with all associated media entries. Vampire with embedded powers GET /vampires/1?_embed=specialPowers Retrieve a vampire profile with all assigned special powers. Get all media GET /media Retrieve a list of all media entries. Media by ID GET /media/3 Retrieve a single media entry. Media for a vampire GET /media?vampireId=1 Retrieve all media linked to a specific vampire. Get all special powers GET /specialPowers Retrieve a list of all powers. Special power by ID GET /specialPowers/1 Retrieve a single special power entry. Powers for a vampire GET /specialPowers?vampireId=7 Retrieve all powers associated with a specific vampire.

docs.title: Example request (GET /vampires)
docs.text: curl -X GET -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://localhost:3000/vampires

docs.title: Create operations (POST)
docs.text:
Use POST to create new resources. The API automatically assigns a unique id to the new entry.

Endpoint Description Required fields POST /vampires Adds a new vampire profile. name, canFly, batMode POST /media Records a new media appearance. type, title, year, vampireId POST /specialPowers Assigns a new power to a vampire. power, vampireId

docs.title: Example request (POST /vampires)
docs.text:
curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"name": "Count Orlok", "canFly": false, "batMode": false}' \
  http://localhost:3000/vampires

docs.title: Update operations (PATCH / PUT)
docs.text:
Use PATCH to update part of a resource, or PUT to replace the resource entirely.

Endpoint Operation Description Example field updates /vampires/{id} PATCH Update one or more fields on a vampire. {"batMode": true} /vampires/{id} PUT Replace a vampire object completely. {"name":"Dracula","canFly":true,"batMode":true} /media/{id} PATCH Update media fields. {"title":"Blade II"} /media/{id} PUT Replace media object entirely. {"type":"movie","title":"Blade II","year":2002,"vampireId":7} /specialPowers/{id} PATCH Update one or more fields of a power. {"power":"Mind Control"} /specialPowers/{id} PUT Replace a power object completely. {"power":"Invisibility","vampireId":4}

docs.title: Example request (PATCH /vampires/7)
docs.text:
curl -X PATCH -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"batMode": true}' \
  http://localhost:3000/vampires/7

docs.title: Example request (PUT /media/3)
docs.text:
curl -X PUT -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"type":"movie","title":"Blade II","year":2002,"vampireId":7}' \
  http://localhost:3000/media/3

docs.title: Delete operations (DELETE)
docs.text:
Use DELETE to remove a resource by ID.

Endpoint Description /vampires/{id} Delete a vampire profile. /media/{id} Delete a media entry. /specialPowers/{id} Delete a special power entry.

docs.title: Example request (DELETE /media/3)
docs.text: curl -X DELETE http://localhost:3000/media/3

docs.title: PATCH /media references

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
At least one field must be provided.

Parameter Description Type id (required) The media ID integer title (optional) New title of the media string year (optional) Updated release year integer vampireId (optional) Associated vampire ID integer

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 200 Update successful Media 400 Invalid update payload ApiError 404 Media not found ApiError

docs.title: Example command
docs.text:
curl -X PATCH \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"year": 2010}' \
  http://{base_url}/media/1

docs.title: Parameters

docs.title: Responses

docs.title: Parameters

  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"name": "Selene", "canFly": false, "batMode": false, "id": 1}' \
  http://{base_url}/vampires/1

docs.title: Tutorial: Creating a complete vampire profile
docs.text:
This tutorial demonstrates how to use the POST method to add a new vampire entity to the database, along with their media appearance and special power.

The goal of this tutorial is to show you how to:

  • Create a new vampire profile using the /vampires resource
  • Link a media appearance to the vampire using the /media resource
  • Assign a special power to the vampire using the /specialPowers resource

This tutorial should take approximately 10 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Confirm that the json-server app is running with the vampy_db.json database. For more information, see Becoming familiar: Getting started with the Vampy API.

docs.title: Procedure
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal.

  2. Run the following cURL command using the POST method. This command creates the core entry to the /vampires resource.

    
curl -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{
    "name": "Edward Cullen",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false
}' http://localhost:3000/vampires

    The API returns the new vampire object, which includes a unique id assigned by the server. For example:

    {
"name": "Edward Cullen",
"canFly": false,
"batMode": false,
"id": 8
}

  3. Run the following cURL command using the POST method to add the movie Twilight to the /media resource. Include the vampireId generated from Step 2.

    
curl -X POST \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "type": "film", 
    "title": "Twilight",
    "year": 2008,
    "vampireId": 8
}' \
http://localhost:3000/media

    The API returns the new power object with its own unique id. For example:

    {
"type": "film",
"title": "Twilight",
"year": 2008,
"vampireId": 8,
"id": 5
}

  4. Run the following cURL command using the POST method to add the power Enhanced Speed to the /specialPowers resource. Include the vampireId generated from Step 2.

    
curl -X POST \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "power": "Enhanced Speed", 
    "vampireId": 8
}' \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers

    The API returns the new power object with its own unique id. For example:

    {
"power": "Enhanced Speed",
"vampireId": 8,
"id": 8
}

docs.title: Completion and validation
docs.text:
1. Run the following cURL command using the GET method to confirm the changes:

    curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/8?_embed=specialPowers

    The response includes the base vampire object with an array of powers:

    {
"name": "Edward Cullen",
"canFly": false,
"batMode": false,
"id": 8,
"specialPowers": [
    {
    "power": "Enhanced Speed",
    "vampireId": 8,
    "id": 8
    }
]
}

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
Now that you understand how to create a complete vampire profile, you can:

  • Learn how to filter vampires by traits in the Filtering Vampires by Trait tutorial
  • Learn how to update vampire information in the Updating Vampire Information tutorial
  • Learn how to manage media appearances in the Managing Media Appearances tutorial
  • Review the Reference documentation for complete details on all API operations

docs.title: Tutorial: Creating a Vampire Profile in Postman
docs.text:
This tutorial shows how to build a basic POST /vampires request in Postman. You'll add the request to the Vampy API collection, wire it to collection variables, and verify the response.

This tutorial should take approximately 5 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Postman Desktop or Web app
  • Vampy API collection and environment imported from the postman folder of this repository
  • json-server running locally with the vampy_db.json database

docs.title: Procedure
docs.text:
1. Open Postman and select the Vampy API workspace or collection.

  2. Make sure the Vampy API Local environment is active. Confirm it contains a baseUrl variable pointing to http://localhost:3000.

  3. In the Vampy collection, duplicate the existing POST /vampires request or create a new request named Create vampire:

  4. Set the method to POST.

  5. Set the URL to {baseUrl}/vampires.

  6. On the Headers tab, ensure Content-Type is set to application/json.

  7. On the Body tab, choose raw + JSON and paste sample data:

{
  "name": "Suki Nightwind",
  "canFly": true,
  "batMode": false
}
  1. Click Send. Postman returns the newly created object, including its generated id. Copy that id.

docs.title: Completion and validation
docs.text:
1. In Postman, switch to a GET {baseUrl}/vampires/{lastVampireId} request.
  2. Click Send to confirm the vampire you created now exists.
  3. Check the response body to ensure name, canFly, and batMode match your input.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• Learn how to filter vampires by trait in Retrieving Vampires by Trait in Postman.
  • Practice editing or deleting records in Updating or Removing Vampires in Postman.
  • Explore the CLI equivalent in Creating a Complete Vampire Profile.

docs.title: Tutorial: Filtering vampires by trait
docs.text:
This tutorial demonstrates how to use the GET method with multiple query parameters to filter the entire /vampires resource for profiles that match specific traits.

The goal of this tutorial is to show you how to:

  • Filter vampires by a single trait using query parameters
  • Combine multiple filters to find vampires matching specific criteria
  • Find all "Classic Cinematic Vampires"—entities that can fly and can transform into a bat

This tutorial should take approximately 10 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Confirm that the json-server app is running with the vampy_db.json database. For more information, see Becoming familiar: Getting started with the Vampy API.

  • Basic familiarity with query parameters (e.g., ?key=value).

docs.title: Procedure
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal.

  2. Use the canFly boolean to narrow down the list to only those vampires capable of flight by running the following GET command:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires?canFly=true

    The API returns a JSON array containing only vampires where canFly is true. For example:

    [
{
    "id": 3,
    "name": "David",
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": false
},
{
    "id": 4,
    "name": "Strigoi",
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": true
},
{
    "id": 5,
    "name": "Count Dracula",
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": true
},
{
    "id": 6,
    "name": "The Count",
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": true
}
]

  3. To narrow the results, run the following GET command, which adds the batMode property to the query string and combines the filter with canFly parameter:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires?canFly=true&batMode=true

    The API returns a smaller, more filtered list. This list contains only the "Classic Cinematic Vampires" who possess both traits (Strigoi, Count Dracula, and The Count).

    [
{
    "id": 4,
    "name": "Strigoi",
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": true
},
{
    "id": 5,
    "name": "Count Dracula",
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": true
},
{
    "id": 6,
    "name": "The Count",
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": true
}
]

  4. Optional: Verify that filters work in reverse. For example, the following command queries canFly=false and batMode=false within the GET command:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires?canFly=false&batMode=false

    The following vampires are returned:

    [
{
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Selene",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false
},
{
    "id": 2,
    "name": "Peter Loew",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false
},
{
    "id": 7,
    "name": "Blade",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false
}
]

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
Now that you understand how to filter vampires by traits, you can:

  • Learn how to create a complete vampire profile in the Creating a Complete Vampire Profile tutorial
  • Learn how to update vampire information in the Updating Vampire Information tutorial
  • Review the Reference documentation for complete details on GET operations for the /vampires resource

docs.title: Tutorial: Managing Media Appearances
docs.text:
This tutorial demonstrates how to work with the /media resource using GET, POST, and PATCH methods. You'll learn how to retrieve, create, and update media appearances linked to vampires.

The goal of this tutorial is to show you how to:

  • Retrieve media appearances for a specific vampire
  • Add new media appearances to the database
  • Update existing media entries

This tutorial should take approximately 10 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Confirm that the json-server app is running with the vampy_db.json database. For more information, see Becoming familiar: Getting started with the Vampy API.

  • Basic familiarity with the GET method and query parameters.

docs.title: Part 1: Retrieving media appearances
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal.

  2. Retrieve all media appearances in the database by running the following GET command:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/media

    The API returns a list of all media entries:

    [
    {
        "id": 1,
        "type": "movie",
        "title": "Underworld",
        "year": 2003,
        "vampireId": 1
    },
    {
        "id": 2,
        "type": "television",
        "title": "Sesame Street",
        "year": 1972,
        "vampireId": 6
    },
    ...
]

  3. Filter media by a specific vampire using the vampireId query parameter. Run the following command to get all media for Count Dracula (id: 5):

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/media?vampireId=5

    The API returns only media linked to that vampire:

    [
    {
        "id": 3,
        "type": "book",
        "title": "Dracula",
        "year": 1897,
        "vampireId": 5
    }
]

  4. Retrieve a single media entry by its ID:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/media/1

    The API returns the specific media entry:

    {
    "id": 1,
    "type": "movie",
    "title": "Underworld",
    "year": 2003,
    "vampireId": 1
}

docs.title: Part 2: Creating new media appearances
docs.text:
1. Add a new media appearance using the POST method. Run the following command to add a movie for Selene (vampireId: 1):

    
curl -X POST \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "type": "movie",
    "title": "Underworld: Evolution",
    "year": 2006,
    "vampireId": 1
}' \
http://localhost:3000/media

    The API returns the new media entry with an auto-generated id:

    {
    "type": "movie",
    "title": "Underworld: Evolution",
    "year": 2006,
    "vampireId": 1,
    "id": 5
}

  2. Verify the new media entry was created by retrieving all media for Selene:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/media?vampireId=1

    The response now includes both media entries:

    [
    {
        "id": 1,
        "type": "movie",
        "title": "Underworld",
        "year": 2003,
        "vampireId": 1
    },
    {
        "id": 5,
        "type": "movie",
        "title": "Underworld: Evolution",
        "year": 2006,
        "vampireId": 1
    }
]

docs.title: Part 3: Updating media appearances
docs.text:
1. Update an existing media entry using the PATCH method. Run the following command to correct the year for the media entry you just created:

    
curl -X PATCH \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "year": 2006
}' \
http://localhost:3000/media/5

    The API returns the updated media entry:

    {
    "id": 5,
    "type": "movie",
    "title": "Underworld: Evolution",
    "year": 2006,
    "vampireId": 1
}

  2. Update multiple fields at once. Run the following command to update both the title and type:

    
curl -X PATCH \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "title": "Underworld: Evolution (Extended Cut)",
    "type": "film"
}' \
http://localhost:3000/media/5

    The API returns the updated entry:

    {
    "id": 5,
    "type": "film",
    "title": "Underworld: Evolution (Extended Cut)",
    "year": 2006,
    "vampireId": 1
}

docs.title: Completion and validation
docs.text:
Verify your changes by retrieving the updated media entry:

curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/media/5

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
Now that you understand how to manage media appearances, you can:

  • Learn how to work with special powers in the Working with Special Powers tutorial
  • Learn how to remove resources in the Removing Resources tutorial
  • Review the Reference documentation for complete details on the /media resource

docs.title: Postman Tutorials Overview
docs.text: The Vampy API Postman tutorials walk through three common CRUD workflows: creating a new vampire, filtering existing vampires by trait, and updating or deleting a record. Each tutorial highlights the tabs and scripts you need inside Postman to replicate the CLI-based procedures.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, make sure you have:

  • Postman Desktop or Web app installed
  • The Vampy API Postman environment imported from the postman folder (see Getting started with the Vampy API)
  • The json-server app running with the vampy_db.json database

docs.title: Available tutorials
docs.text: Tutorial Description Operations covered Creating a Vampire Profile in Postman Build and send a basic POST /vampires request and store the returned id POST for /vampires Retrieving Vampires by Trait in Postman Filter vampires with query parameters (for example, canFly=true) GET with query parameters for /vampires Updating or Removing Vampires in Postman Apply PATCH/PUT updates and delete records safely PATCH, PUT, DELETE for /vampires

docs.title: Need help?
docs.text:
If you get stuck while using Postman:

  • Confirm the correct environment is selected and baseUrl points to http://localhost:3000
  • Review the Reference documentation for payload details
  • Check Swagger documentation to compare request/response schemas
  • Reset collection variables or re-import the environment if IDs get out of sync

docs.title: Tutorial: Removing Resources
docs.text:
This tutorial demonstrates how to use the DELETE method to remove resources from all three Vampy API resources: /vampires, /media, and /specialPowers.

The goal of this tutorial is to show you how to:

  • Delete vampire profiles
  • Delete media appearances
  • Delete special power entries
  • Understand the implications of deleting resources

This tutorial should take approximately 10 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Confirm that the json-server app is running with the vampy_db.json database. For more information, see Becoming familiar: Getting started with the Vampy API.

  • Basic familiarity with the GET method to verify deletions.

docs.title: Important considerations
docs.text: Warning: Deleting a resource is permanent. When you delete a vampire, consider whether you also want to delete associated media and special powers, as they will remain in the database but be orphaned (their vampireId will reference a non-existent vampire).

docs.title: Part 1: Deleting a special power
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal.

  2. First, verify the special power exists by retrieving it:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers/3

    The API returns the power entry:

    {
    "id": 3,
    "power": "Being a vampire",
    "vampireId": 2
}

  3. Delete the special power using the DELETE method:

    
curl -X DELETE \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers/3

    The API returns an empty response (HTTP 200) on successful deletion.

  4. Verify the deletion by attempting to retrieve the deleted power:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers/3

    The API returns a 404 Not Found error, confirming the resource has been deleted.

docs.title: Part 2: Deleting a media appearance
docs.text:
1. Verify the media entry exists:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/media/2

    The API returns the media entry:

    {
    "id": 2,
    "type": "television",
    "title": "Sesame Street",
    "year": 1972,
    "vampireId": 6
}

  2. Delete the media appearance:

    
curl -X DELETE \
http://localhost:3000/media/2

    The API returns an empty response (HTTP 200) on successful deletion.

  3. Verify the deletion:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/media/2

    The API returns a 404 Not Found error.

docs.title: Part 3: Deleting a vampire profile
docs.text:
1. Before deleting a vampire, check what media and powers are associated with it. Retrieve the vampire with embedded resources:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/2?_embed=media&_embed=specialPowers

    The API returns the vampire profile with associated resources:

    {
    "id": 2,
    "name": "Peter Loew",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false,
    "media": [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "type": "movie",
            "title": "Vampire's Kiss",
            "year": 1988,
            "vampireId": 2
        }
    ],
    "specialPowers": []
}

  2. Delete the vampire profile:

    
curl -X DELETE \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/2

    The API returns an empty response (HTTP 200) on successful deletion.

  3. Verify the deletion:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/2

    The API returns a 404 Not Found error.

  4. Note: The associated media entry still exists but is now orphaned (its vampireId references a deleted vampire). You can verify this:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/media/1

    The media entry still exists:

    {
    "id": 1,
    "type": "movie",
    "title": "Vampire's Kiss",
    "year": 1988,
    "vampireId": 2
}

    If you want to clean up orphaned resources, you would need to delete them separately or update their vampireId to reference a different vampire.

docs.title: Completion and validation
docs.text:
Verify that all deletions were successful by listing the remaining resources:

# List remaining vampires
curl -X GET http://localhost:3000/vampires

# List remaining media
curl -X GET http://localhost:3000/media

# List remaining special powers
curl -X GET http://localhost:3000/specialPowers

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
Now that you understand how to remove resources, you have completed the full CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations for all resources. You can:

  • Review the Reference documentation for a complete overview of all operations
  • Explore the Swagger documentation for interactive API exploration
  • Practice combining operations by creating, updating, and managing complete vampire profiles

docs.title: Tutorial: Retrieving Vampires by Trait in Postman
docs.text:
This tutorial walks through a simple GET /vampires request that filters results by trait. You'll configure query parameters inside Postman, inspect the returned data, and save an example for quick comparisons.

The goal of this tutorial is to show you how to:

  • Add and manage query parameters in Postman
  • Send a GET request to /vampires with filters such as canFly=true
  • Save a successful response as an example for future reference

Estimated time to complete: 5 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Postman Desktop or Web app
  • Vampy API collection and environment imported from the postman folder of this repository
  • json-server running locally with the vampy_db.json database

docs.title: Procedure
docs.text:
1. Open Postman and select the Vampy collection.

  2. Create or open a request named List vampires by trait.

  3. Set the method to GET.

  4. Set the URL to {{baseUrl}}/vampires.

  5. Switch to the Params tab and add query parameters:

  6. canFly → true

  7. Optional: Add additional filters such as batMode=false or name=Selene.

  8. Click Send. Verify the response status is 200 and the body shows only vampires matching your filters.

Save the request to keep the test.

  1. To capture a baseline response, click Save Response > Save as example, give it a descriptive name such as canFly=true, and click Save.

docs.title: Completion and validation
docs.text:
1. Modify a parameter (for example, toggle canFly to false) and click Send to confirm the filters update dynamically.
  2. Compare the new response with the saved example to understand output differences.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• Create new vampires to test different traits in Creating a Vampire Profile in Postman.
  • Learn to update or delete a record once you find it in Updating or Removing Vampires in Postman.

docs.title: Tutorials Overview
docs.text: The Vampy API command-line interface (CLI) tutorials provide step-by-step, hands-on instructions for working with the API. Each tutorial focuses on specific operations and workflows to help you build practical skills.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
All tutorials assume that you have:

  • The json-server app running with the vampy_db.json database. For setup instructions, see Getting started with the Vampy API.
  • Basic familiarity with REST APIs and HTTP methods
  • Access to a terminal and curl command-line tool

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
If you're new to the Vampy API, we recommend starting with one of the following tutorials:

  1. Creating a Complete Vampire Profile - Learn how to create a new vampire profile and link it to media and special powers using the POST method.

  2. Filtering Vampires by Trait - Learn how to use query parameters to filter vampire profiles based on specific traits.

docs.title: Creating and reading resources
docs.text: Tutorial Description Operations covered Creating a Complete Vampire Profile Create a new vampire profile with associated media and special powers POST for /vampires, /media, and /specialPowers Filtering Vampires by Trait Filter vampire profiles using query parameters GET with query parameters for /vampires

docs.title: Updating resources
docs.text: Tutorial Description Operations covered Updating Vampire Information Update vampire profiles using PATCH and PUT methods PATCH and PUT for /vampires Managing Media Appearances Retrieve, create, and update media appearances GET, POST, and PATCH for /media Working with Special Powers Retrieve, create, and update special powers GET, POST, and PATCH for /specialPowers

docs.title: Deleting resources
docs.text: Tutorial Description Operations covered Removing Resources Delete vampires, media, and special powers DELETE for all resources

docs.title: Need help?
docs.text:
If you encounter issues while following a tutorial:

  • Review the Reference documentation for detailed API specifications
  • Check the Swagger documentation for interactive API exploration
  • Ensure your json-server is running and accessible at http://localhost:3000

docs.title: Tutorial: Updating or Removing Vampires in Postman
docs.text:
This tutorial covers the basic update (PATCH/PUT) and delete (DELETE) workflows for the /vampires resource using Postman. You'll edit an existing record, replace it entirely, and then remove it safely.

The goal of this tutorial is to show you how to:

  • Reuse the lastVampireId (or any ID) when targeting specific records
  • Send partial updates with PATCH and replace the resource with PUT
  • Delete the record while running guardrail tests

Estimated time to complete: 5 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Postman Desktop or Web app
  • Vampy API collection and environment imported from the postman folder of this repository
  • A valid vampire id (for example, the lastVampireId captured in Creating a Vampire Profile in Postman)
  • json-server running locally with the vampy_db.json database

docs.title: Part 1: PATCH partial updates
docs.text:
1. Open the Update vampire (PATCH) request or create a new one:
  2. Method: PATCH

  3. URL: {{baseUrl}}/vampires/{{vampireId}}

  4. On the Body tab choose raw + JSON and supply only the fields you want to change:

{
  "canFly": false
}
  1. Click Send and confirm the response body shows the updated field while keeping other values intact.

docs.title: Part 2: PUT full replacements
docs.text:
1. Duplicate the PATCH request and rename it Replace vampire (PUT).

  2. Change the method to PUT and provide the complete resource representation:

{
  "name": "Suki Nightwind",
  "canFly": false,
  "batMode": true
}
  1. Click Send. The server replaces the entire record with the new data (missing fields are removed), so double-check the response payload.

docs.title: Part 3: DELETE the record
docs.text:
1. Create a request named Delete vampire:
  2. Method: DELETE

  3. URL: {{baseUrl}}/vampires/{{lastVampireId}}

  4. Optional safety test: on the Tests tab add the following snippet to confirm the deletion:

pm.test("Vampire deleted", () => pm.response.to.have.status(200));

  1. Click Send. The API returns the removed object as confirmation.

  2. Run a follow-up GET {{baseUrl}}/vampires/{{lastVampireId}}. You should receive 404 or an empty response, indicating the record was successfully removed.

docs.title: Completion and validation
docs.text:
• Ensure both PATCH and PUT responses reflect the new values you supplied.
  • Confirm the DELETE response contains the removed object and that subsequent GET calls fail.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• Re-create test data with Creating a Vampire Profile in Postman.
  • Practice more targeted queries with Retrieving Vampires by Trait in Postman.
  • Consult the Reference documentation for the full schema.

docs.title: Tutorial: Updating Vampire Information
docs.text:
This tutorial demonstrates how to use the PATCH and PUT methods to update vampire profiles in the /vampires resource. You'll learn when to use each method and how they differ.

The goal of this tutorial is to show you how to:

  • Use PATCH to update specific fields on a vampire profile
  • Use PUT to replace an entire vampire profile
  • Understand the differences between these two update methods

This tutorial should take approximately 10 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Confirm that the json-server app is running with the vampy_db.json database. For more information, see Becoming familiar: Getting started with the Vampy API.

  • Basic familiarity with the GET method to retrieve vampire profiles.

docs.title: Understanding PATCH vs PUT
docs.text: Method Use case Fields required Behavior PATCH Update one or more specific fields Only fields you want to change Partial update - other fields remain unchanged PUT Replace entire resource All required fields (name, canFly, batMode) Complete replacement - missing fields may be lost

docs.title: Part 1: Using PATCH to update specific fields
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal.

  2. First, retrieve the current vampire profile to see its current state. Run the following GET command:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/7

    The API returns the current Blade profile:

    {
    "name": "Blade",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false
    "id": 7
}

  3. Use PATCH to update only the batMode field. Run the following command:

    
curl -X PATCH \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "batMode": true
}' \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/7

    The API returns the updated vampire object. Notice that only batMode changed, while name and canFly remained unchanged:

    {
    "name": "Blade",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": true,
    "id": 7
}

  4. Use PATCH again to update multiple fields at once. Run the following command to update both canFly and batMode:

    
curl -X PATCH \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": true
}' \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/7

    The API returns the updated profile:

    {
    "name": "Blade",
    "canFly": true,
    "batMode": true,
    "id": 7
}

docs.title: Part 2: Using PUT to replace the entire resource
docs.text:
1. Use PUT to completely replace the vampire profile. Important: With PUT, you must provide all required fields. Run the following command:

    
curl -X PUT \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "name": "Blade",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false
}' \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/7

    The API returns the replaced vampire object:

    {
    "name": "Blade",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false,
    "id": 7
}

docs.title: Completion and validation
docs.text:
Run the following command to verify the final state of the vampire profile:

curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/7

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
Now that you understand how to update vampire profiles, you can:

  • Learn how to update media appearances in the Managing Media Appearances tutorial
  • Learn how to update special powers in the Working with Special Powers tutorial
  • Learn how to remove resources in the Removing Resources tutorial

docs.title: Tutorial: Working with Special Powers
docs.text:
This tutorial demonstrates how to work with the /specialPowers resource using GET, POST, and PATCH methods. You'll learn how to retrieve, create, and update special powers linked to vampires.

The goal of this tutorial is to show you how to:

  • Retrieve special powers for a specific vampire
  • Add new special powers to the database
  • Update existing special power entries

This tutorial should take approximately 20 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Confirm that the json-server app is running with the vampy_db.json database. For more information, see Becoming familiar: Getting started with the Vampy API.

  • Basic familiarity with the GET method and query parameters.

docs.title: Part 1: Retrieving special powers
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal.

  2. Retrieve all special powers in the database by running the following GET command:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers

    The API returns a list of all special powers:

    [
    {
        "id": 1,
        "power": "Day-walking",
        "vampireId": 7
    },
    {
        "id": 2,
        "power": "Enhanced Marksmanship",
        "vampireId": 1
    },
    {
        "id": 3,
        "power": "Being a vampire",
        "vampireId": 2
    },
    ...
]

  3. Filter special powers by a specific vampire using the vampireId query parameter. Run the following command to get all powers for Blade (id: 7):

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers?vampireId=7

    The API returns only powers linked to that vampire:

    [
    {
        "id": 1,
        "power": "Day-walking",
        "vampireId": 7
    }
]

  4. Retrieve a single special power by its ID:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers/1

    The API returns the specific power entry:

    {
    "id": 1,
    "power": "Day-walking",
    "vampireId": 7
}

  5. Retrieve a vampire profile with embedded special powers using the _embed parameter:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/vampires/7?_embed=specialPowers

    The API returns the vampire profile with all associated powers:

    {
    "id": 7,
    "name": "Blade",
    "canFly": false,
    "batMode": false,
    "specialPowers": [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "power": "Day-walking",
            "vampireId": 7
        }
    ]
}

docs.title: Part 2: Creating new special powers
docs.text:
1. Add a new special power using the POST method. Run the following command to add a power for Blade (vampireId: 7):

    
curl -X POST \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "power": "Vampire Slaying",
    "vampireId": 7
}' \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers

    The API returns the new power entry with an auto-generated id:

    {
    "power": "Vampire Slaying",
    "vampireId": 7,
    "id": 8
}

  2. Verify the new power was created by retrieving all powers for Blade:

    
curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers?vampireId=7

    The response now includes both powers:

    [
    {
        "id": 1,
        "power": "Day-walking",
        "vampireId": 7
    },
    {
        "id": 8,
        "power": "Vampire Slaying",
        "vampireId": 7
    }
]

docs.title: Part 3: Updating special powers
docs.text:
1. Update an existing special power using the PATCH method. Run the following command to update the power name:

    
curl -X PATCH \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "power": "Expert Vampire Slaying"
}' \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers/8

    The API returns the updated power entry:

    {
    "id": 8,
    "power": "Expert Vampire Slaying",
    "vampireId": 7
}

  2. Update the vampireId to reassign a power to a different vampire. Run the following command:

    
curl -X PATCH \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
    "vampireId": 1
}' \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers/8

    The API returns the updated entry with the new vampireId:

    {
    "id": 8,
    "power": "Expert Vampire Slaying",
    "vampireId": 1
}

docs.title: Completion and validation
docs.text:
Verify your changes by retrieving the updated special power:

curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers/8

You can also verify by checking which powers are now associated with the updated vampire:

curl -X GET \
http://localhost:3000/specialPowers?vampireId=1

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
Now that you understand how to work with special powers, you can:

  • Learn how to remove resources in the Removing Resources tutorial
  • Review the Reference documentation for complete details on the /specialPowers resource
  • Learn how to update vampire profiles in the Updating Vampire Information tutorial
